ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Applications and knowledge of stress, shear, and other forces. Knowledge of materials, forces, and methods for solving problems.
This course taught me the basics of mechanical engineering statics. I learned about concepts such as stress, deflections within beams, and how to find reaction forces within components of beams.

In this course we learned how to analyze different kinds of structures. We learned about moments of inertia, shear, stress, and moments (couples). Professor Adrezin also did a great job of showing us how the concepts we learned about were applied in a workplace environment.

It's my first course in mechanical engineering and engineering in general. I pretty enjoyed it and found it so relatable to my previous knowledge in physics and maths. I learned how to draw free-body diagrams (basically the first of solving any problems), different kinds of support and cable systems, some mechanics of materials, and stuff like thermostats, thermal expansion, and viscoelasticity, which are so useful in the real world.
I developed skills to apply what I learned in physics to real world strength and deformation situations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The only weakness was not being able to cover everything thoroughly with the accelerated timeline.

This course was a great intro class for the beginning of the mechanical engineering track at Yale. It was only unfortunate that due to the heightened pace of it being a summer course, we had to go fast through a lot of the subject area.
I thought the class was organized pretty well, I can't think of any weaknesses. The problem sets and quizzes were fair.

The course was pretty organized, and the assignments and quizzes are closely related to what was taught in class. So by reading the textbooks, solving the problems, and following the lectures, I found it manageable, even though I have not taken any engineering courses before.

A strength was the application to real world examples and connection to previous topics. One weakness was how the classes were laid out, not following the chapters of the book. It got a little confusing bouncing around chapters.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course because as an introductory engineering course, it was an engaging first outlook into the work of an engineer.
Yes! It is required for the Mechanical Engineering track, but it also is a great class that introduces a lot of engineering concepts that are useful in all areas.
I thought the problems we encountered were pretty interesting and Professor Adrezin was great. I think this class would interest even someone who isn't in the major!
Definitely, a great intro course not only for future courses in both engineering dynamics and mechanics of materials.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in engineering. It gives a great background to all different engineering disciplines.
